ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: White light luminous properties and energy transfer mechanism of rare earth ions in Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics, College of Optical and Electronic Information
Affiliation.OrgName: Huazhong University of Science and Technology
Hubei Institute of Measurement and Testing Technology

OrgAddress.Street: Mao Dian Shan Road, Auto Electronic Industry Park, East Lake Hi-Tech Park

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We report on a kind of Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped borosilicate glasses which can emit white light luminescence combined with red, green and blue fluorescence. In this manuscript, the energy transfer mechanism between Ce3+ and Tb3+ ions, Ce3+ and Sm3+ ions, and Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions is discussed by analysis of the steady and transient luminescence spectra of the doped ions. Based on the energy transfer mechanism, the near-ideal white light emission from the Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses with the color coordinate (x=0.335, y=0.337) has been observed under 350-nm excitation. Meanwhile, the calculated parameters such as color rendering index (78–81) and color temperature (4717–5372 K), characterizing luminous properties, show that the glasses can be potential candidates for displays and lighting.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Recently, white light emitting diodes (W-LEDs) which are called the next generation solid-state lighting (SSL) sources have been paid more and more attention. Compared with the traditional lighting sources, W-LEDs have apparent advantages such as compact size, longer lifetime, lower energy consumption, higher reliability and being environment-friendly [1–3]. Nowadays, the W-LED consisting of a blue InGaN LED chip and yellow emitting YAG: Ce3+ phosphor has been commercialized due to the advantage of low cost and high brightness. In this kind of W-LEDs, the blue light from InGaN chip is used to excite YAG: Ce3+ phosphor. Then the yellow light can be mixed with the remaining blue light from the chip and create the white light. However, these W-LEDs have some inherent drawbacks, as the color rendering index (CRI) and color temperature (CT) are hard to be adjusted suitably for human vision [4–6]. Another kind of W-LEDs is a so-called tri-color W-LED, in which the white light is created by exciting the tri-color (red, green and blue) phosphor with the ultraviolet (UV) chip [7, 8]. Compared with the former, this kind of W-LEDs has a better color rendering index [2].

All the above W-LEDs need encapsulated phosphors in epoxy resin coated on ultraviolet (UV) or blue LED chips. However, the epoxy resin which is required in phosphor lamp tends to deteriorate at high temperature. Compared with the phosphor used in the preparation of W-LEDs, the rare earth (RE) ions doped luminescence glasses can solve the above problem due to the advantages of easiness in forming any shape, higher transparency, simpler manufacture procedure, lower production cost and no need of epoxy resin [1, 9, 10]. Thus, it is feasible that luminescence glasses replace the phosphorous W-LEDs, which, to the best authors’ knowledge, has been scarcely reported [11]. For white light emitting luminous glass, it is necessary to consider the glass matrix stability and the luminescence spectra distribution. In this manuscript, the borate-silicate glass system has been chosen as carrier of rare earth ions. It combines the advantages of the stability of silicate glass and the higher rare-earth-ion solubility of borate glass. The photon energy of visible light is in the range of 14285 to 25000 cm−1. However, the phonon energy of silica glass is about 1100 cm−1 which is much lower than the photon energy. Moreover, the glass matrix used in our manuscript is borosilicate glass, for which the phonon energy is less than 1100 cm−1. So the effect of phonon energy on the visible light emission can be very limited. Since few rare earth ions can simultaneously emit red, green and blue luminescence under longer wavelength UV excitation, it is necessary to dope different rare earth ions in a glass matrix. Energy transfer effect between the three kinds of RE ions has to be considered and utilized. In this manuscript, we report on a kind of Ce-Tb-Sm co-doped white light luminous glass. The steady and transient fluorescence spectra were measured to characterize the luminescence properties and explore the energy transfer mechanism between Ce3+ and Tb3+ ions, Ce3+ and Sm3+ ions, and Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions. Finally, the important parameters like color coordinate, CRI, and CT of the Ce-Tb-Sm co-doped glass have been calculated. The results show that the glasses are a potential candidate for luminous applications.

Section1.Heading: Experiment
Section1.Para: The composition of the glass used in this experiment is 50SiO2-14B2O3-8ZnO-8MgO-3.5ZrO2-4.5Na2O-0.4Gd2O3-0.03Sb2O3-10Al2O3-xCe2O3-yTb2O3-zSm2O3. The analytical grade SiO2, H3BO3, ZnO, MgCO3, ZrO2, Na2CO3, Gd2O3, Sb2O3, Al2O3 and high purity CeO2, Tb4O7 and Sm2O3 were used as the raw materials for glass melting. The weighted materials within 16 g were mixed thoroughly and then put into the corundum crucible to melt at 1580 ∘C for 2 hours in air. The melt was poured on the preheated steel mold for quenching and then annealed for 2 hours at 550 ∘C to obtain the final samples. The samples were cut into 15 mm×15 mm×1 mm size and polished for subsequent measurement. Since the glasses were melt at such high temperature, the concentrations of RE ions in the obtained might derive from those of raw compositions. To ensure the accuracy of the concentration, we measured the concentration of the relevant ions using an AXIS-ULTRA DLD-600W X-ray electron spectrometer. The excitation and emission spectra in the ultraviolet (UV) and visible wavelength were recorded on a JASCO FP-6500 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a tunable excitation source ranging from 200 to 750 nm. The absorption spectra were performed by a Lambda 35 UV-Vis spectrophotometer equipped with a tunable wavelength ranging from 190 to 2000 nm. Photoluminescence decay was measured by using FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. All of the measurements were carried out at room temperature. To ensure the data of the measurement precisely, we put every sample at the same position and kept them at the same angle related to the excitation light.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the UV-visible absorption spectra of the glass matrix of borosilicate glass (SiB), the Ce3+ singly doped (Ce), the Tb3+ singly doped (Tb), the Sm3+ singly doped (Sm) and the Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped (CTS) borosilicate glasses. The insert of the figure shows the absorption spectra of the matrix, the Sm3+-doped glass and the Tb3+-doped glass ranging from 240 to 300 nm. The singly doped glasses and the co-doped glass have a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol%, a Tb3+ concentration of 1.10 mol%, and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.45 mol%. It can be seen that the matrix has only a strong absorption band around 200 nm which is corresponding to the intrinsic absorption of SiB [1]. For Ce3+-doped glass, the UV-absorption cut-off wavelength is red-shifted compared with the glass matrix, which is due to the allowed 4f → 5d transition of Ce3+ ions. For Tb3+-doped and Sm3+-doped glasses, the UV-absorption cut-off wavelengths are little red-shifted as can be clearly seen from the insert, which can be ascribed to the f→f transition. The absorption band around 404 nm in the absorption spectra of Sm3+-doped and Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses can be ascribed to the intrinsic 4f absorption of Sm3+ ions. However, It is worth noticing that the absorption of the samples in the visible region is low enough to ignore, which is very important for the high optical transparency of the samples that is essential to realize high fluorescent quantum yield at visible wavelength band [12].
Fig. 1
The UV-Visible absorption spectra of the host glass, Ce3+, Tb3+, Sm3+ singly doped glasses, and Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glass. The insert shows the absorption spectra of the host glass, Sm3+-doped and Tb3+-doped glasses ranging from 240 to 300 nm

Figure 2 shows the normalized excitation spectra (left side) and emission spectra (right side) of a series of glasses singly doped with Ce3+ (A), Tb3+ (B) and Sm3+ (C). The Ce3+-doped glass has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol%, Tb3+-doped glass has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.10 mol% and Sm3+-doped glass has a Sm3+ concentration of 1.45 mol%. The excitation wavelengths are 350, 373, and 404 nm, respectively, and the monitoring wavelengths are 405, 543, and 605 nm.
Fig. 2
Normalized excitation spectra (left) and emission spectra (right) of Ce3+-doped (a), Tb3+-doped (b) and Sm3+-doped (c) borosilicate glasses. The excitation wavelengths are 350, 373, and 404 nm, respectively, and the monitoring wavelengths are 405, 543, and 605 nm

For the Ce3+-doped glass 2(a), there is a broad excitation band ranging from 270 to 400 nm due to the 4f → 5d transition of Ce3+ ions, and a strong emission band centered at 405 nm attributed to the 5d → 4f transition of Ce3+ ions [1, 13–15]. For the Tb3+-doped glass 2(b), the excitation spectrum shows five excitation peaks situated at 320, 326, 354, 373 and 487 nm belonging to the 7F6→5D J (J=0, 1, 2, 3 and 4) transition of Tb3+ ions; the emission spectrum contains two blue emission peaks centered at 415 and 438 nm ascribed to the 5D3→7F J (J=5, 4) transition of Tb3+ ions; and four green emission peaks situated at 488, 543, 588 and 622 nm corresponding to the 5D4→7F J (J=6, 5, 4, 3) transition of Tb3+ ions. For Sm3+-doped glass 2(c), there are seven excitation bands centered at 327, 339, 369, 404, 440, 475 and 528 nm assigned to the electronic transitions of 6H5/2→4G5/2, 6H5/2→4H11/2, 6H5/2→4F9/2, 6H5/2→4F7/2, 6H5/2→4G9/2, 6H5/2→4I11/2, 6H5/2→4F3/2, respectively, and four emission peaks at 568, 605, 650 and 711 nm identified to the electronic transition of 4G5/2→6H J (J=5/2, 7/2, 9/2 and 11/2) [16, 17].

Figure 3(a) shows a significant spectral overlap between the emission spectrum of Ce3+ ions and the excitation spectra of Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions; Fig. 3(b) shows a significant spectral overlap between the emission spectrum of Tb3+ ions and the excitation spectrum of Sm3+ ions. The concentration of Ce3+ ions is 0.22 mol%, that of Sm3+ ions is 1.45 mol%, and of Tb3+ ions is 1.10 mol%. The excitation wavelengths for Ce3+ and Tb3+ ions are 350 and 373 nm, respectively. The emission wavelengths for Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions are 543 and 605 nm, respectively. According to the Dexter theory for energy transfer, there is energy transfer probability between Ce3+ and Tb3+, between Ce3+ and Sm3+ and also between Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions by nonradiative energy transfer associated with resonance between donors and acceptors. It can be seen that the Ce3+, Tb3+, Sm3+ are blue, green and red emitters, respectively. Furthermore, Ce3+ may be efficient sensitizer to transfer energy to Tb3+ and Sm3+, and Tb3+ can efficiently transfer energy to Sm3+.
Fig. 3
The combination of the emission spectrum (a) of Ce3+, the excitation spectra (b and c) of Tb3+ and Sm3+ (a), and the combination of the emission spectrum (d) of Tb3+ and the excitation spectrum (c) of Sm3+ (b). The excitation wavelengths for Ce3+ ions and Tb3+ ions are 350 and 373 nm, respectively. The emission wavelengths for Tb3+ ions and Sm3+ ions are 543 and 605 nm, respectively

To manifest the energy transfer process, we measured the emission spectra of the relevant ions’ singly doped and co-doped samples which are shown in Fig. 4.
Fig. 4
Emission spectra of Ce3+ singly doped, Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped and Tb3+ singly doped (a); Ce3+ singly doped, Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped, and Sm3+ singly doped (b) and Tb3+ singly doped, Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped and Sm3+ singly doped (c) borosilicate glasses. The excitation wavelength is 350 nm for all the glasses. The inserts show the fluorescence photographs corresponding to Tb3+ singly doped, Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped, Sm3+ singly doped and Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped glasses, respectively, under 350 nm UV lamp irradiation

Figure 4(a) shows the emission spectra of Ce3+ singly doped, Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped and Tb3+ singly doped borosilicate glasses under 350-nm excitation. Ce3+ singly doped sample has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol%, Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped sample has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.21 mol% and a Tb3+ concentration of 1.07 mol%, and Tb3+ singly doped sample has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.10 mol%. The emission spectrum of Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped glass is the combination of the emission of Ce3+ and the emission of Tb3+. It presents that the emission of Tb3+ in Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped glass is much more enhanced than that in Tb3+ singly doped glass, while the emission of Ce3+ in Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped glass decreases half as that in Ce3+ singly doped glass. That is due to the energy transfer from Ce3+ to Tb3+ which can be expressed as (5d,4f)→(7F6,5D3). Figure 4(b) shows the emission spectra of Ce3+ singly doped, Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped and Sm3+ singly doped borosilicate glasses under 350-nm excitation. Ce3+ singly doped sample has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol%, Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped sample has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol% and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.46 mol%, and Sm3+ singly doped glass has a Sm3+ concentration of 1.45 mol%. The emission spectrum of Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass is the combination of the emission of Ce3+ and the emission of Sm3+. As for Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass, the emission of Sm3+ ions increases compared with Sm3+ singly doped glass, while the emission of Ce3+ ions decreases compared with Ce3+ singly doped glass. The energy transfer from Ce3+ to Sm3+, which can be expressed as (5d,4f)→(6H5/2,4G5/2), could be used to explain this result. It is interesting that compared with Ce3+ singly doped glass, there is a spectrum hole at 404 nm in Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass under 350-nm excitation. For this phenomenon, it is suggested that there is a strong reabsorption of Sm3+ ions to the emission of Ce3+. Figure 4(c) shows the emission spectra of Tb3+ singly doped, Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped and Sm3+ singly doped borosilicate glasses under 350-nm excitation. Tb3+ singly doped sample has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.10 mol%, Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped sample has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.11 mol% and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.42 mol%, and Sm3+ singly doped glass has a Sm3+ concentration of 1.45 mol%. The emission spectrum of Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass is the combination of the emission of Tb3+ and the emission of Sm3+. Compared with Tb3+ singly doped glass and Sm3+ singly doped glass, the emission of Sm3+ and the emission of Tb3+ in Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass tend to increase and decrease, respectively. That is due to the energy transfer from Tb3+ to Sm3+ which can be express as (5D4,7F6)→(6H5/2,4G5/2).

The inserts show the luminescent photographs corresponding to Tb3+-doped, Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped, Sm3+-doped and Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped borosilicate glasses under 350 nm UV light irradiation. It is clear that the brightness of Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped and Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped samples is much higher than that of Tb3+-doped and Sm3+-doped samples, indicating that the efficient energy transfer from Ce3+ ions to Tb3+ ions and Sm3+ ions occurs.

To quantitatively analyze the energy transfer process of the three ions, we measured the photoluminescence decay of the singly doped and co-doped glasses which are shown in Figs. 5 and 6. Figure 5 shows the normalized fluorescence decay of Ce3+ emission at 405 nm in sample a, sample b and sample c under 350-nm excitation. Sample a has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol%. Sample b has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.21 mol% and a Tb3+ concentration of 1.07 mol%. Sample c has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.22 mol% and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.46 mol%. The mechanism of the energy transfer between Ce3+ and Tb3+ and Sm3+ can be analyzed using the Dexter’s theory or Inokuti–Hirayama formula. We measured the fluorescence decay of 5d → 4f emission of Ce3+ ions in samples a, b and c. It is found that the fluorescence decay cannot be exactly simulated by dipole–dipole interaction or multipolar interaction on their own. It is suggested that the Ce3+ ions doped in borosilicate glass can be classified into two types due to the distance between Ce3+ ions, one isolated and with no interaction with other ions, another with multipolar interaction with other ions. Therefore, the fluorescence from the former should decay exponentially and the later should decay according to Inokuti–Hirayama formula.
Fig. 5
Normalized fluorescence decay of Ce3+ emission at 405 nm in singly doped and co-doped borosilicate glasses under 350-nm excitation. Sample a is the Ce3+ singly doped glass with the concentration of 0.22 mol% Ce3+. Sample b is the Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped glass with the concentration of 0.21 mol% Ce3+ and 1.07 mol% Tb3+. Sample c is the Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass with the concentration of 0.22 mol% Ce3+ and 1.46 mol% Sm3+. The lines in colors are fitted lines of decay curves corresponding to samples a, b and c, respectively
Fig. 6
Normalized fluorescence decay of Tb3+ (5D4→7F5, 543-nm) emission in singly doped and co-doped borosilicate glasses under 373-nm excitation. Sample d is the Tb3+ singly doped glass with the concentration of 1.10 mol% Tb3+. Sample e is the Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped glass with the concentration of 1.11 mol% Tb3+ and 1.42 mol% Sm3+. The lines in colors are fitted lines of decay curves corresponding to samples d and e, respectively

In such a case, the decay fitting was performed using the sum of exponential decay formula and an Inokuti–Hirayama formula (here, the d-d interaction type is considered) [18], that is:
1
$$\begin{aligned} I(t) =&A\exp\biggl(-\frac{t}{\tau }\biggr) \\ &{}+(1-A)\exp\biggl[- \frac{t}{\tau }-\sqrt{\pi }\biggl(\frac{C}{C_0}\biggr) \biggl( \frac{t}{\tau }\biggr)^{1/2}\biggr] \end{aligned}$$ The first term on the right side represents the emission without multipolar interaction and the second term is the electric dipole–dipole interaction. Also, A is the contributive parameter, τ is the intrinsic lifetime of single ion (56 ns for the our sample doped with 0.05 mol% Ce3+), C is the number of acceptors per unit volume,
$C_{0}^{-1}$ is the volume of donor’s sphere of influence (
${=}4\pi R_{0}^{3}/3$ , R 0 being the critical separation between donor and acceptor, at which the transfer rate is equal to the radiative decay rate), the ratio of C/C 0 means the number of acceptors in donor’s sphere of influence. The fitted curves are depicted in Fig. 5. The overall fitting result shows that the analysis of the two-component exponential fitting yields a relatively good fit between the theoretical calculation and the measured data. The fitting parameters of samples a, b and c are shown in Table 1. From the results it can be seen that the contributive parameter A decreases in the co-doped samples compared with that in the singly doped samples, which means that with the doping of Tb3+ and Sm3+, dipole–dipole interaction will dominate the emission. The ratio of C/C 0 increases in the co-doped samples. In a glass system, the C 0 value usually has less variation; at this point, the value of C increases greatly. The C is the number of acceptors per unit volume.
Table 1
Parameters for the fitted equation for the 5d → 4f transition of Ce3+ in samples a, b and c
Sample
A
C/C 0
a (Ce3+)
0.04
2.0
b (Ce3+-Tb3+)
0.03
2.3
c (Ce3+-Sm3+)
0.02
2.15

Furthermore, the mean lifetime (τ) and the energy transfer efficiency (η ET) are calculated using Eqs. (2) and (3):
2
$$ \tau =\int^{\infty}_{0}I(t)t\,dt\Big/\int ^{\infty}_{0}I(t)\,dt $$ and
3
$$ \eta_{\mathrm{ET}}=1-\tau '/\tau $$ where I(t) is the luminescence intensity as a function of time t. The energy transfer efficiency η ET is defined as the ratio of donors that are depopulated by energy transfer to the acceptors over the total number of donors being excited. In our system, the 5d level of Ce3+ acts as the donor and the 5D3 level of Tb3+ and 4G5/2 level of Sm3+ act as the acceptor. And τ′ is the lifetime of donor in co-doped samples while τ is the lifetime of donor ions singly doped sample. The mean lifetime for samples a, b and c is 45, 40.2 and 41 ns, respectively, and the energy transfer efficiency for the Ce3+-Tb3+ co-doped sample and Ce3+-Sm3+ co-doped sample is 28.2 and 26.8 %, respectively.

Figure 6 shows the normalized fluorescence decay of Tb3+ (4D4→7F5 543-nm) emission in samples d and e under 373-nm excitation. Sample d has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.10 mol%. Sample e has a Tb3+ concentration of 1.11 mol% and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.42 mol%. Assuming that the interaction scheme of the energy transfer between Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions is dipole–dipole interaction, the 5D4 decay curves could be analyzed using the well-known direct quenching mechanism. So that the Inokuti–Hirayama formula representing the direct quenching could be used to analyze the experimental data:
4
$$ I(t)=I(0)\exp\biggl[-\biggl(\frac{t}{\tau }\biggr)-\biggl( \frac{C}{C_0}\biggr)\sqrt{\pi}\biggl(\frac{t}{\tau }\biggr)^{1/2} \biggr] $$ where I(0) represents the initial intensity of emission, and τ is the intrinsic lifetime of a single ion (2.57 ms for our sample doped with 0.05 mol% Tb3+). The other parameters have the same meaning as in Eq. (1). A relatively good fit is achieved between the measured data and the fitting curves, and a little deviation may be due to the cross-relaxation which can be expressed as
$$\bigl({}^{5}\mathrm{D}_{3},{}^{7} \mathrm{F}_{6}\bigr)\rightarrow\bigl({}^{5} \mathrm{D}_{4},{}^{7}\mathrm{F}_{0}\bigr) $$ The parameter C/C 0, the mean lifetime τ and the energy transfer efficiency η ET are calculated according to Eqs. (2) and (3). The parameter C/C 0 for samples d and e is 0.03 and 0.25, respectively. The lifetimes for samples d and e are 2.54 and 2.06 ms, respectively. The energy transfer efficiency for Tb3+-Sm3+ co-doped sample is 19.8 %.

Based on the emission, excitation spectra and decay lifetime measurements and the energy level scheme of Ce3+, Tb3+, Sm3+ in Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped borosilicate glass are shown in Fig. 7.
Fig. 7
Energy level scheme which reflects the luminescence characteristic of Ce3+, Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions co-doped in borosilicate glass

The solid line with upward arrow represents absorption process causing electron transition from ground state to excited state; the solid line with downward arrow represents electron transition from higher energy level to lower energy level with energy released; the curve line with downward arrow represents the nonradiative relaxation process; the dotted line with arrow represents the energy transfer between two ions. ET1, ET2 and ET3 represent energy transfer from Ce3+ to Tb3+ ions, Tb3+ to Sm3+ ions, and Ce3+ to Sm3+ ions, respectively. The process of ET1 and ET3 will lead to the decreased emission of Ce3+ ions and increased emission of Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions. And the process of ET2 will lead to the emission of Tb3+ ions to decline while that of Sm3+ ions to increase. According to the Dexter theory, energy transfer process can be enhanced if the distance between donors and acceptors is shortened. So, if we increase the concentration of Sm3+ in Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped borosilicate glass, the blue and green emission of Ce3+ and Tb3+ will decrease and the red emission of Sm3+ will increase. Thereby, the white light emission can be achieved through changing the concentration of Sm3+ ions to change the proportion of blue, green and red light.

By analysis of luminous mechanism of the three ions, the Ce3+, Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions are introduced into one glass matrix. The proportion of blue, green and red light is appropriately adjusted by changing the concentration of Sm3+ ions.

To obtain the optimal white-light emission, we prepared some samples by adjusting the concentration of different dopants. Figure 8 shows the emission spectra of Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses under 350-nm UV light irradiation. Sample 8a has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.16 mol%, a Tb3+ concentration of 1.18 mol%, and a Sm3+ concentration of 0.96 mol%. Sample 8b has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.18 mol%, a Tb3+ concentration of 1.19 mol%, and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.13 mol%. Sample 8c has a Ce3+ concentration of 0.20 mol%, a Tb3+ concentration of 1.20 mol%, and a Sm3+ concentration of 1.44 mol%. The white light spectra emitting by Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses is made a spectral resolution according to the intrinsic emission of Ce3+, Tb3+ and Sm3+. The peak function used in the process is Gauss function. In Fig. 8(a), the dashed line corresponds to Ce3+ emission with a center at 408 nm and full width at half maximum (FWHM) of ∼71 nm. The short dashed line corresponds to Tb3+ emission with centers at 489, 543, 590, and 618 nm and FWHM of ∼35, ∼17.7, ∼23.5, ∼21.2 nm, respectively. The short dotted line corresponds to Sm3+ emission with centers at 564, 601 and 648 nm, and FHWM of ∼17.7, ∼17.7 and ∼20 nm, respectively. It can be seen that by just increasing the concentration of Sm3+ ions, both the blue emission of cerium and the green emission of terbium decrease while the red emission of samarium increase. The blue emission of cerium decreases as the concentration of Sm3+ increases, which, as we discussed above, can be ascribed to the energy transfers between Ce3+ and Sm3+ ions. The more is the concentration of Sm3+ ions, the more Ce3+ emission would be suppressed and the more emission of Sm3+ facilitated. The green emission of terbium decreases as the concentration of Sm3+ increases, which can be ascribed to the energy transfer from Tb3+ to Sm3+ ions. The insert of Fig. 8(b) shows the luminescent photographs of samples 8a, 8b and 8c.
Fig. 8
Emission spectra of Ce3+/Tb3+/Sm3+ co-doped glasses under 350-nm UV light excitation (a). The insert (b) is the luminescent photographs corresponding to samples 8a, 8b and 8c. The five stars in CIE (x,y) (c) numbering 1, 2 and 3 show the color coordination of samples 8a, 8b and 8c, respectively

To further understand the luminous characteristic of these glasses, we calculate the chromaticity coordinate (x,y), color temperature (CT), and color rendering index which is represented by R
a , according to the standard CIE, 1931. Color temperature can be obtained by comparing the chromaticity coordinate (u
k ,v
k ) of luminescence samples with the isothermal of blackbody radiation trajectory in UCS graph. It equals to the temperature of the isothermal of blackbody radiation trajectory which is approaching the chromaticity coordinate of the luminescence sample. The results are shown in Table 2.
Table 2

The result of the chromaticity coordinate is marked in 1931 (x,y) chromaticity diagram using five-pointed star. The five stars numbered 1, 2 and 3 correspond to samples 8a, 8b and 8c. It can be seen that the emission light of the glasses is all in white light region, and the emission of sample 8c is much closer to the ideal white light (x=0.333, y=0.333). It demonstrates that the color rendering index of samples 8a, 8b and 8c is in the range of 78–81. The color temperatures of the samples are low. Although the luminous properties of the samples are suitable for the sensation of human eyes, more effort should be paid to increase the color rendering index and decrease the color temperature of Ce-Tb-Sm co-doped melting borosilicate glass, which is relegated for the work.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In conclusion, the glasses impregnated with Ce3+, Tb3+ and Sm3+ ions were prepared successfully. It is suggested that there arise energy transfer between Ce3+ and Tb3+, Ce3+ and Sm3+ and Tb3+ and Sm3+. By adjusting the concentration of different dopants, a serial of white light emission borosilicate glasses were obtained under long wavelength UV light excitation. The color coordinate shows the emission of these samples is very close to the ideal white light. The color temperature of the samples is very low and the color rendering index of the samples is high. Due to the advantage of white light emitting glass, this kind of glass will have potential application in the field of optical fiber, domestic illumination and LED displays.
